cards.name: Atlantic Flying Fish
cards.flavorText: Can glide 200 meters on wing-like pectoral fins, reaching 60 km/h to escape predators.

cards.name: Black Mullet
cards.flavorText: Feeds by scooping mud and filtering algae through its gill rakers — a living vacuum cleaner.

cards.name: Blobfish
cards.flavorText: At 1,200m depth its gelatinous body is firm and functional — it only 'melts' at surface pressure.

params.title: Choose a Rival's prey to consume

cards.name: Celestial Eye Goldfish
cards.flavorText: Selectively bred in China for 300+ years — its upward-locked eyes cannot look forward at all.

cards.name: Ghost Eel
cards.flavorText: A white garden eel that burrows tail-first into sand and sways with the current to catch plankton.

cards.name: Golden Angelfish
cards.flavorText: Angelfish form monogamous pairs and both parents fiercely guard their eggs from intruders.

cards.name: Leafy Seadragon
cards.flavorText: Males carry the eggs on a spongy patch under their tail — females play no role after mating.

cards.name: Portuguese Man O' War Legion
cards.flavorText: Not one animal but a colony of specialized organisms called zooids, each with a unique function.

cards.name: Psychedelic Frogfish
cards.flavorText: Discovered in 2009 off Indonesia — it bounces along the seafloor instead of swimming.

cards.name: Rainbow Mantis Shrimp
cards.flavorText: Its strike accelerates faster than a .22 caliber bullet, creating cavitation bubbles that boil the water.

cards.name: Rainbow Sardines
cards.flavorText: Sardine schools can number in the millions, creating 'bait balls' that attract every predator nearby.

cards.name: Rainbow Trout
cards.flavorText: Their pink flesh comes from carotenoids in their crustacean diet — farm-raised ones are naturally gray.

cards.name: Spearfish Remora
cards.flavorText: Remoras attach via a modified dorsal fin that acts as a suction cup — the bond is entirely voluntary.

params.title: Choose a predator to gain Ambush

cards.name: Blue-ringed Octopus
cards.flavorText: Carries enough tetrodotoxin to kill 26 adults — and there is no known antidote.

cards.name: Cannibal Fish
cards.flavorText: Lancetfish are among the few fish known to regularly eat their own species — stomachs often contain smaller lancetfish.

cards.name: Black Drum
cards.flavorText: Produces a drumming sound using muscles against its swim bladder — audible from above the water.

cards.name: Deep-sea Angler
cards.flavorText: The male fuses permanently to the female's body, sharing her bloodstream — losing his eyes and organs.

cards.name: Electric Eel
cards.flavorText: Not a true eel — it's a knifefish that must surface to breathe air, producing up to 860 volts.

cards.name: Golden Dorado
cards.flavorText: South America's top freshwater predator — it leaps clear out of the water to snatch birds mid-flight.

cards.name: King Salmon
cards.flavorText: Chinook salmon navigate home using Earth's magnetic field, then stop eating and die after spawning.

cards.name: Kingfish
cards.flavorText: King mackerel migrate over 1,000 miles seasonally and can sprint at 40 mph in short bursts.

cards.name: Silver King
cards.flavorText: Tarpon can gulp air using a primitive lung-like swim bladder, letting them survive in oxygen-poor water.

cards.name: Sailfish
cards.flavorText: The fastest fish in the ocean at 110 km/h — it folds its dorsal sail flat for maximum hydrodynamics.

cards.name: Wahoo
cards.flavorText: One of the fastest fish alive at 80 km/h, with razor teeth that can sever wire fishing leaders.

cards.name: Alligator Gar
cards.flavorText: A living fossil from the Cretaceous — its ganoid scales are so hard, Native Americans used them as arrowheads.

cards.name: Atlantic Bluefin Tuna
cards.flavorText: Warm-blooded for a fish — it heats its muscles and brain to hunt in frigid deep water at 70 km/h.

cards.name: Goliath Grouper
cards.flavorText: Can weigh over 360 kg and swallows prey whole using a powerful vacuum created by its massive mouth.

cards.name: Shortfin Mako
cards.flavorText: The fastest shark at 74 km/h — one of few sharks that can leap fully out of the water when hunting.

cards.name: Swordfish
cards.flavorText: Uses its bill to slash through fish schools, stunning prey with lateral swipes before circling back to eat.

cards.name: Beluga Whale
cards.flavorText: The only whale that can change its facial expression — and echolocates with a flexible, oil-filled melon.

cards.name: Narwhal
cards.flavorText: Its tusk is actually a left canine tooth with 10 million nerve endings — it senses temperature and salinity.

cards.name: Tiger Shark
cards.flavorText: Nicknamed the 'garbage can of the sea' — stomachs have contained license plates, tires, and suits of armor.

params.title: Choose a carrion predator to copy

cards.name: Black Marlin
cards.flavorText: Clocked at 130 km/h — likely the fastest fish on Earth, though its speed is difficult to measure.

cards.name: Great White Shark
cards.flavorText: Can detect one drop of blood in 100 liters of water and sense electrical fields from muscle contractions.

cards.name: Orca
cards.flavorText: Orca pods have unique dialects and hunting techniques passed down through generations — a true culture.

cards.name: Net
cards.flavorText: Gill nets have been used since the Stone Age — modern drift nets can stretch over 50 km long.

cards.name: Fish Food
cards.flavorText: Commercial fish feed converts at a 1.2:1 ratio — among the most efficient protein production in agriculture.

cards.name: Flood
cards.flavorText: Flash floods reshape entire river ecosystems in hours, redistributing nutrients across floodplains.

cards.name: Sunken Treasure
cards.flavorText: The ocean floor holds an estimated 20 million tons of gold — but it's too diluted to extract profitably.

cards.name: Harpoon
cards.flavorText: Toggling harpoons revolutionized whaling — the head pivots after entry, making extraction impossible.

cards.name: Angler
cards.flavorText: Anglerfish lures glow via symbiotic bioluminescent bacteria that live nowhere else in nature.

cards.name: Edible
cards.flavorText: Trophic cascades show that removing one predator can collapse an entire ecosystem within years.

params.title: Choose a predator to gain Edible

cards.name: Washout
cards.flavorText: Storm surges can push seawater miles inland, stripping habitats bare and resetting coastal ecosystems.

cards.name: Undertow
cards.flavorText: Undertows pull at up to 8 feet per second — faster than an Olympic swimmer's sustained speed.

params.title: Choose a Rival's creature to strip abilities

cards.name: Cramp
cards.flavorText: Cold water cramps occur when muscles lose electrolytes — marine mammals counter this with high myoglobin stores.

cards.name: Riptide
cards.flavorText: Rip currents form when waves break unevenly — they account for 80% of ocean rescue calls worldwide.

cards.name: Maelstrom
cards.flavorText: The Moskstraumen maelstrom off Norway generates whirlpools strong enough to pull small boats underwater.
